awd_titl_txt: Chemical Studies Utilizing Back Scattering Interferometry
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Bornhop at Vanderbilt University and Professor Flowers at Lehigh University are developing a unique sensing technique that greatly simplifies the measurement of molecular interactions.  The method is termed backscattering interferometry (BSI).  BSI is a simple and inexpensive way of studying chemical reactions, like those used to understand how a drug molecule works, to monitor environmental pollutes, or to diagnose disease from a blood test.  BSI works by placing a sample into a microscale, glass or plastic, liquid-filled chamber that is illuminated by a laser like those used in a grocery store checkout.  When the laser light is reflected back from the chamber it forms a set of alternating bright and dark spots (interference pattern) that are captured by a camera.  These patterns are exquisitely sensitive to chemical or biochemical changes of the solution in the chamber.  Most tools used to measure chemical interactions require the solution to be modified by tagging, labeling, or attachment to the chamber surface, yet in BSI none of these modifications are required to make the measurements.  With support from this grant Professors Bornhop and Flowers are developing and validating the physical model for these "free-in-solution" measurements, by showing that the BSI signal originates from property changes in the solution, such as molecular shape (conformation) and the amount of water closely associated with the molecule (hydration).  These properties have not previously been recognized or measured.  The BSI model, termed the Free-solution Response Function (FreeSRF), is being expanded to a wide array of chemical and biochemical interactions (such as protein-to-protein, DNA-to-DNA interactions)to determine if FreeSRF can be used to predict chemical structural changes. Professor Bornhop is working with companies closely to commercialize a benchtop, compressed BSI that will allow more users to apply the developed approach to their own research. The students engaged in the project receive a broad range of scientific training, ranging from the construction and modification of the instrument, to the development and benchmarking of bioassays, to the development and refinement of the FreeSRF models. Professor Bornhop is also actively engaged in K-12 outreach through the Vanderbilt Student Volunteers for Science (VSVS) program and the Tennessee Governors' School program.  

Back-scattering interferometry (BSI) is the refractive index (RI) sensor used in the studies performed under this NSF project.  BSI is a free-solution, label-free technique with sensitivity that rivals fluorescence assays, is compatible with a wide range of analytes, can be used with complex matrices, and is fully quantitative.  Professors Bornhop and Flowers are studying how intrinsic property changes report molecular binding events at unprecedented sensitivities (pM-fM) in complex milieu, even when the individual binding partners are undetectable by BSI.  Having shown that interferometric, free-solution, label-free studies performed on BSI report conformation and hydration changes, two groups are working together to develop a model that provides a theoretical and experimental underpinning for the phenomenon being measured by BSI and other label-free methods. In addition, building on their theory that refines, or redefines, the basis for label-free free-solution RI measurements, the Free-Solution Response Function (FreeSRF), they are expanding investigations to a more diverse set chemical and biochemical interactions, including DNA and RNA hybridization, metal ion-chelator binding, and protein folding.  It is anticipated that the research will impact on how scientists generally think about label-free sensing, going beyond BSI and SPR, leading to the development of new sensing/imaging systems and novel approaches to the analysis of ligand-protein interactions.  A newly developed, highly compensated scattering interferometer (CSI), is being combined with FreeSRF to enable translation of the methodology to a broader scientific community.   This bench-top CSI for mix-and-read free-solution assays enables a wide array of applications and serve as a foundation for an experiment-based curriculum that teaches students how understanding interaction determinations are critical in chemistry, biochemistry, molecular biology, and medical technology.

por.por_cntn:
Under Grant CHE-1610964, we advanced the fundamental understanding of how molecules change or structurally rearrange during chemical or biochemical reactions.  Our research also showed how these molecular changes impact the level of hydration, or the amount of water, associated with the interacting molecules.  We showed how these waters of hydration have been underestimated, and that they play a key role in accurately defining the solution-phase properties of chemical and biochemical interactions on a molecular level.  Collectively, these observations resulted in a paradigm shift in our understanding of how to study molecular interactions in the absence of labels (free in solution) and without manipulating the participating species with approaches like surface attachment.  Recognizing the limitations of the current theoretical description of solution-phase chemical/biochemical interactions, we developed and validated a more accurate model to describe these fundamental processes.  While the previous model simply considered the reaction-induced change of thickness for interactions studied on a surface, our model provides a more complete and generalized description of the expected solution properties for chemical/biochemical binding.  Our model, called the Free-solution Response Function (FreeSRF) enabled the accurate prediction of both signal magnitude and signal direction for a wide array of bi-molecular interactions.  For example, (Figure 1) illustrates the excellent correlation between the experimentally observed and theoretically predicted refractive index (RI) signal, (change in speed of light) for two biochemical reactions.  This observation stands in stark contrast to the existing mass-weighted / refractive index, which fails to accurately predict the magnitude (and direction) of the solution-phase binding-induced RI signal.  The FreeSRF model was used to accurately describe solution-phase interactions across a wide array of diverse interacting species, including, ion-protein, small molecule-protein, protein-protein, DNA-DNA, RNA-small molecule, DNA-small molecule.  Our studies molecular/ionic structural and hydration changes indicates that the conventional theory should be reconsidered. 

 

Practically, the existing techniques used to perform highly sensitive, rapid and specific chemical and biochemical tests still have limitations.  These include instrument and chemical complexity, modest sensitivity, and the need to work in relatively pure or non-native matrices.

 

Under Grant CHE-1610964 we also demonstrated a unique test measurement methodology.  This research involved first designing, constructing and testing ultra-high sensitivity, sample volume constrained (nanoliter) universal sensor to measure changes in solution-phase composition, e.g. the RI.  RI detectors currently exist and are used for many applications such as determining the amount of sugar in juice, blood protein, and in characterizing polymers.  Our unique RI detector, shown in Figure 2, consists of an inexpensive laser light source, a capillary tube and a camera.  Due to the special optical configuration of this interferometer, it can be operated without active temperature stabilization (control) allowing for rejection of environmental back-ground noise and greatly simplifying the instrument compared to existing technologies.  The device represents a first step toward realizing a hand-held/field-compatible sensor, with performance not impacted by miniaturization.

 

Recognizing the need for a bench-top measurement tool, we modified the interferometer so that it could be used to analyze more than a few samples per day.  Marriage of a commercial droplet generator and a syringe pump with the interferometer (Figure 2), enabled demonstration of a medium through-put, (30-40 sample/reference pairs per day), high sensitivity reader, based on a relatively simple components. Using this technology we showed a plethora of sensing applications were possible, including cancer biomarker determination, opiate measurements and drug development studies.  These investigations represent broader societal impacts and positive outcomes.  If success is continued as in the past 4 years, we predict the impact of our research on society to be quite far reaching.  Our observations and educational activities have the potential to accelerate drug discovery, support the deployment of personalized medicine, enable the measurement of important indicators of environmental damage, and potentially provide quantitative metrics for afflictions such as Post Traumatic Stress Disorder. 

Two examples of impact are improved opiate quantification for addressing neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) and providing a rapid response to chemical threats.  Dealing with addicted newborns is an important unaddressed aspect of the opiate epidemic, with the need to non-invasively test neonates.  Our relatively simple, near-patient urine test (Figure 3), could facilitate neonate patient management in the rural hospital or clinic.  Being able to detect smaller amounts of the opiate in urine, also enables earlier and extended dose determination over existing methods.

Exposure to organophosphorus compounds (OPs) represent a significant chemical threat to humans due to their use as weapons, their potential storage hazards, and from their continued use agriculturally.  The approach demonstrated under this grant to quantify organophosphorus nerve agents (OPNA) represents an innovative step toward developing a simplified, field-deployable, method to rapidly quantify these toxic materials.  The capability to rapidly quantify OPNA?s is critical to the DOD/CDC mission of identifying chemical threats, as well as in crop testing and other environmental sensing applications.
